G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore is within the original jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2 because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County and Defendant conducts business in Middlesex County.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, § 3 because, among other things, Defendant transacts business in Massachusetts and the claims asserted herein arise from Defendant’s conduct within the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A..proposition: Plaintiff has complied with, or is not subject to, all applicable statutory and procedural prerequisites for filing this action, including the statute of limitations set forth in G.L. c. 260, § 2A.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or occupier who invites the public onto its premises for business purposes owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors against foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and adopting a general duty of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors. While the quoted passage is only a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707–08 expressly states that an occupier must exercise reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe for lawful visitors, which necessarily includes those invited onto the premises for business purposes. Thus, the case supports the proposition, though not in the precise, business-invitee-specific terms stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: "We now hold that the proper test of the landowner's duty is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others, and that the duty of care is owed to all lawful visitors. The common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished… The occupier of land is under a duty to exercise reasonable care to all lawful visitors to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: In premises liability actions, a plaintiff must show that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care, breached that duty, and that the breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements of a negligence claim, including duty, breach, causation, and damages, in the context of analyzing the premises-related negligence claim against the homeowner. Although the case is not styled purely as a generic ‘premises liability’ case, it is a negligence action concerning conditions and activities on the defendant’s property, and the opinion clearly affirms that a plaintiff must prove duty, breach, causal relation, and resulting damage.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: In premises liability actions, a plaintiff must show that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care, breached that duty, and that the breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and resulting damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states the elements the plaintiffs must prove in their negligence claims: breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss (damages), and that the defendant’s negligence caused that loss. Although the case is not exclusively about premises liability, it is a premises-type negligence action and the court is reciting the general duty–breach–causation–damages framework, which matches the proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965)… Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: A store owner is liable when it (a) created a dangerous condition, (b) had actual knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to remedy it, or (c) should have known of the condition because it existed for such a length of time that the owner, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition recites the traditional tripartite rule for store-owner liability: creation of the condition, actual knowledge, or constructive knowledge based on the condition’s duration. Sheehan describes that traditional rule in order to explain that Massachusetts is moving away from it and formally adopts the mode-of-operation approach, which relaxes the notice requirement in certain self-service situations. Thus, the case discusses but does not endorse the proposition as the governing standard; instead, it refines and partially replaces it.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove a grocery store caused a substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the store operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition. … Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach… However, the law has afforded store owners a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct any hazards before liability attaches.”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 683–84 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: A store owner is liable when it (a) created a dangerous condition, (b) had actual knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to remedy it, or (c) should have known of the condition because it existed for such a length of time that the owner, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly restates the traditional Massachusetts premises-liability rule, drawn from Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and Sheehan, that an owner is liable if it caused the condition, had actual knowledge, or the condition existed long enough that the owner should have discovered and remedied it. Although the case’s main focus is on expanding the "mode of operation" doctrine, it clearly affirms the traditional tripartite notice structure that matches the proposition. Thus, it is proper authority for the stated rule.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: Where the condition consists of spillage on the floor of a place of business, the first element is satisfied if the operator of that business “caused [the] substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the ... operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the . . . operator should have been aware of the condition.” Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 782-783.

Federal Nat\u2019l Mortg. Ass\u2019n v..raw_text: Federal Nat’l Mortg. Ass’n v. Hendricks, 463 Mass. 635, 642–43 (2012)
Federal Nat\u2019l Mortg. Ass\u2019n v..proposition: A store is charged with the knowledge of its employees acting within the scope of their employment.
Federal Nat\u2019l Mortg. Ass\u2019n v..case_name: Federal National Mortgage Ass'n v. Hendricks
Federal Nat\u2019l Mortg. Ass\u2019n v..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a statutory foreclosure affidavit is sufficient to establish a prima facie right to possession in a post-foreclosure summary process action. It does not discuss agency principles, imputation of employees’ knowledge to a store or business, or scope of employment. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a store is charged with the knowledge of its employees acting within the scope of their employment.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: The condition of the floor—containing a visible puddle of milk, with cart tracks through it and an employee nearby who had observed the spill—was such that Defendant either knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the hazard and taken appropriate steps to remove or warn of it.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a situation where the hazard was visible, with cart tracks through a puddle and an employee who had observed the spill—facts implying actual or constructive notice. Oliveri, however, involves an unknown hard substance on a stair, with no evidence of how long it had been there or that any employee knew or should have known of it. The court ultimately holds that the circumstantial evidence did not permit an inference that the defendant knew or should have known of the hazard and orders judgment for the defendant, so it does not support the proposition that such facts establish notice and a duty to act.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.… Exceptions sustained. Judgment for the defendant.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: The condition of the floor—containing a visible puddle of milk, with cart tracks through it and an employee nearby who had observed the spill—was such that Defendant either knew or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of the hazard and taken appropriate steps to remove or warn of it.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a situation where there was a visible spill with cart tracks and an employee nearby who had observed it, implying actual or clearly inferable constructive notice. Deagle, by contrast, holds there was insufficient evidence that the store or its employees knew or should have known of the spill: there was no proof how long the oil had been on the floor, no evidence of employee awareness, and only a speculative possibility the cashier could have seen it. The case thus emphasizes the plaintiff’s failure to prove notice, rather than supporting a finding of constructive knowledge on facts like those in the proposition.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers… On the evidence here we think that the negligence of the defendant is left to conjecture.”

Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Thurlow v. Shaw’s Supermarkets, Inc., 49 Mass. App. Ct. 175, 177–78 (2000)
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: A failure to warn or to remedy a known or reasonably discoverable hazardous condition on a commercial premises constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states the duty of a business controller to use due care to keep premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers that are not likely to be known to patrons and that the defendant knows or should know about. The court then affirms liability based on constructive notice of a hazardous water accumulation from melting ice that should have been discovered and remedied, treating that failure as negligence. This aligns with the proposition that failure to warn of or remedy a known or reasonably discoverable hazard breaches the duty of reasonable care.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “One who controls business premises has an obligation ‘to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.’… Based upon that time frame, the obvious nature of the melting, and the fact that at least one store employee was near, the judge concluded that the defendant had constructive notice of the hazard.”

Falden v. Braun, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 1124.raw_text: Falden v. Braun, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 1124 (2011)
Falden v. Braun, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 1124.proposition: A failure to warn or to remedy a known or reasonably discoverable hazardous condition on a commercial premises constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care.

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Causation and damages are established where, as here, Plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable result of slipping on a liquid spill left on the floor in a self-service grocery aisle and Plaintiff in fact suffered physical injury, medical expenses, and lost wages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case does discuss proximate cause and foreseeability, but in the context of a governmental parole decision and an intervening federal action, not a premises-liability slip‑and‑fall in a grocery store. The court ultimately finds that the injury was not a foreseeable result of the Commonwealth’s conduct and that proximate cause is lacking, which is the opposite of what the proposition asserts for a spill‑and‑fall scenario. Thus, Kent v. Commonwealth does not establish or affirm the rule claimed about causation and damages from slipping on a liquid spill in a self‑service grocery aisle.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. … If a series of events occur between the negligent conduct and the ultimate harm, the court must determine whether those intervening events have broken the chain of factual causation….”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 322–23 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: The conduct and omissions of Defendant’s employee who saw the spill “a few minutes” before Plaintiff’s fall and chose to delay cleanup are attributable to Defendant under the doctrines of respondeat superior and vicarious liability.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The case does discuss respondeat superior and vicarious liability, but only in the context of a physician’s malpractice and whether a medical practice group can be held liable for its physician-employee’s treatment decisions. It does not involve premises liability, spills, or an employee observing and delaying cleanup of a hazard, nor does it address attribution of such conduct to an employer. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about an employee who saw a spill and chose to delay cleanup.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment. ... To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, comparative negligence, if any, on the part of Plaintiff does not bar recovery unless Plaintiff’s negligence exceeds the total negligence of the Defendant; any damages awarded shall be diminished in proportion to any causal negligence attributable to Plaintiff.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to prejudgment interest on her damages from the date of commencement of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.
